message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and pelvic pain along with an enlarged, soft, and tender uterus suggest adenomyosis. Endometriosis would present with pelvic pain and may also have dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia, but it would not cause a soft and tender uterus. Leiomyoma would present with uterine enlargement and may cause pelvic pain and menorrhagia, but it would not cause dysmenorrhea. Endometrial carcinoma would not cause uterine enlargement or pelvic pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the physical examination suggest Adenomyosis, which is characterized by the growth of endometrial tissue within the myometrium. Leiomyoma also presents with an enlarged uterus but is typically firm and not tender. Endometriosis can cause pelvic pain and menstrual abnormalities, but does not cause an enlarged or tender uterus unless there is associated adenomyosis. Endometrial carcinoma can cause abnormal uterine bleeding but typically does not cause dysmenorrhea or pelvic pain unless there is associated uterine enlargement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, and it can cause dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and pelvic pain. The other options either have different symptoms or would show different imaging and biopsy findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and pelvic pain suggest a reproductive system disorder. The transvaginal sonogram reveals an enlarged, soft, and tender uterus, which is a characteristic of adenomyosis. Uterine biopsy shows normal-appearing endometrial glands within the myometrium, which further supports the diagnosis of adenomyosis. Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. Leiomyoma is a benign tumor of the smooth muscle tissue of the uterus. Endometrial carcinoma is a type of cancer that arises from the lining of the uterus. These conditions are less likely to present with the symptoms observed in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and pelvic pain are typical of adenomyosis. The enlarged, soft, and tender uterus, along with normal-appearing endometrial glands within the myometrium, are strong indicators of adenomyosis. Endometriosis usually causes infertility, while leiomyoma can cause heavy bleeding but does not involve the glands within the myometrium. Endometrial carcinoma is a possibility, but it is unlikely with normal-appearing endometrial glands on biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenomyosis is characterized by growth of endometrial tissue into the myometrium, which can lead to symptoms such as dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, and pelvic pain, and an enlarged, soft, and tender uterus. Uterine biopsy showing normal-appearing endometrial glands within the myometrium is also consistent with adenomyosis. Endometriosis typically presents with cyclic pelvic pain, dyspareunia, and infertility, and is not typically associated with an enlarged uterus. Leiomyoma is a common benign tumor of the uterine smooth muscle that can cause heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain, but it typically presents as a well-circumscribed, firm mass within the uterus. Endometrial carcinoma typically presents with postmenopausal bleeding, and uterine biopsy would show malignant endometrial cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and transvaginal sonogram suggest adenomyosis, which is characterized by endometrial tissue growing into the myometrium. Endometriosis is characterized by endometrial tissue growing outside the uterus, and leiomyoma is a benign tumor of the smooth muscle in the uterus. Endometrial carcinoma is a type of cancer that can arise from the lining of the uterus, but the biopsy shows normal-appearing endometrial glands within the myometrium, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the transvaginal sonogram results suggest Adenomyosis, which is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium. Uterine biopsy showing normal-appearing endometrial glands further supports this diagnosis. Leiomyoma is characterized by a hard, asymptomatic uterus, while endometriosis is characterized by dyspareunia and cyclic pelvic pain. Endometrial carcinoma would have abnormal endometrial glandular cells on biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest a diagnosis of adenomyosis, which is the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium of the uterus. Endometriosis usually presents with pain outside of menstruation and may have other associated symptoms. Leiomyoma, or uterine fibroids, may also present with these symptoms but typically have a more firm consistency. Endometrial carcinoma is less likely given the normal-appearing endometrial glands on biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings on sonogram and biopsy suggest adenomyosis, which is a condition where the endometrial tissue grows into the myometrium of the uterus. Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue grows outside of the uterus, and leiomyoma is a benign growth of smooth muscle cells in the uterus. Endometrial carcinoma would show abnormal cells on biopsy.
